solution_line_template: The {truffle_dozens} dozen truffles were sold in individual units so a dozen is equal to {dozen} so {truffle_dozens}*{dozen}=<<{truffle_dozens}*{dozen}={total_truffles}>>{total_truffles}
{total_truffles} chocolate truffles, at ${truffle_price_each} each sold for {total_truffles}*{truffle_price_each} = $<<{total_truffles}*{truffle_price_each}={truffle_revenue}>>{truffle_revenue}
The {pretzel_dozens} dozen chocolate pretzels sold in individual units so a dozen is equal to {dozen} so {pretzel_dozens}*{dozen} = <<{pretzel_dozens}*{dozen}={total_pretzels}>>{total_pretzels}
{total_pretzels} chocolate pretzels sold for ${pretzel_price_each} each sold for {total_pretzels}*{pretzel_price_each} = $<<{total_pretzels}*{pretzel_price_each}={pretzel_revenue}>>{pretzel_revenue}
All total, the store made {fudge_revenue}+{truffle_revenue}+{pretzel_revenue} = $<<{fudge_revenue}+{truffle_revenue}+{pretzel_revenue}={total_revenue}>>{total_revenue} from candy sales
